text:
Store, formerly an old tavern, at 1-2 Sheridan Square, east side, seen from the West 4th Street side, looking towards 127-125, 123, 121 Washington Place, the six-story apartment house and the two little houses which can be seen on the north side of Washington Place east of Sheridan Square.
Later in the decade No. 1-2 Sheridan Square will be remodelled, and another story will be added.
1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Grove Street, south side, east from Washington Place to Christopher Street. Also shown, is Washington Place, at, adjoining and east of the (N.E) corner of Grove Street. Building (No. 80 Grove Street) at the corner, is a frame structure with a brick front.

October 4, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

4th Street (right), and Washington Place (left), east from Grove Street, showing also Sheridan Square in the foreground. Sheridan Square is a triangle with its apex pointing west and located at the western end of Washington Place (originally West 5th Street); the northern side is the northern side of Washington Place, and the southern side follows the line of West 4th Street (formerly Asylum Street). Sheridan Square house numbers begin on the short eastern side, which was originally the eastern end of Reason Street (now the eastern section of Barrow Street, q.v.), and follow in order clockwise around Sheridan Square.

P. L. Sperr.

June 24, 1933.

88-90 Grove Street, south side, between Washington and Waverly Places.

May 2, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 28. Another ragamuffin at 91 Christopher Street, the same location portrayed in Nos. 25, 27.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 29. Boys dressed as girls, Grove Street at Washington Place, Sheridan Square. "Their receipts had been "only three cents" at about 2 P. M.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 30. Ragamuffins on a Greenwich Village front stoop, location uncertain.
November 30, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
703-705 Broadway, north of the N.W. corner of West 4th Street.
February 7, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

John G. Wendel, furrier, lived in 705 Broadway from 1842 - 1854 and moved from there to his mansion at 39th St & Fifth Ave.
Info from Mary Watkins.

88, 90, and 92 Grove Street, southeast side, between Washington and Waverly Places. No. 92 is the six story apartment building. The two private dwellings at the right bear No's. 88 and 90. They face the triangular park separating Grove from Christopher Street.

1940

Alexander.Alland, photo

"The Colonnade houses on Broadway" p.173
Broadway, No.718

Pelletreau, William S.
Early New York houses with historical - genealogical notes.
New York: Francis P. Harper, 1900.
